messages.content: You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: The patient is a 26-year-old female, referred to Physical Therapy for low back pain.  The patient has a history of traumatic injury to low back.  The patient stated initial injury occurred eight years ago, when she fell at a ABC Store.  The patient stated she received physical therapy, one to two visits and received modality treatment only, specifically electrical stimulation and heat pack per patient recollection.  The patient stated that she has had continuous low-back pain at varying degrees for the past eight years since that fall.  The patient gave birth in August 2008 and since the childbirth, has experienced low back pain.  The patient also states that she fell four to five days ago, while mopping her floor.  The patient stated that she landed on her tailbone and symptoms have increased since that fall.  The patient stated that her initial physician examination with Dr. X was on 01/10/09, and has a followup appointment on 02/10/09.
When did your pain begin?
I've had low back pain for about eight years now.
Is there any injury?
Yeah, it started when I fell in an A B C store.
How old are you now?
I'm twenty six.
What kind of treatments have you had for this low back pain?
Yeah, I got referred to P T, and I went, but only once or twice, um, and if I remember right, they only did the electrical stimulation, and heat.
I see, how has your pain progressed over the last eight years?
It's been pretty continuous, but it's been at varying degrees, sometimes are better than others.
Do you have any children?
Yes, I had my son in August of two thousand eight, and I've had back pain since giving birth.
Have you had any falls since the initial one?
Yes, I fell four or five days ago while I was mopping the floor.
Did you land on your lower back again?
Yes, right onto my tailbone.
Did that make the low back pain worse?
Yes.
Have you seen any other doctors for this issue?
Yes, I saw Doctor X on January tenth two thousand nine, and I have a follow up appointment scheduled for February tenth two thousand nine.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: As mentioned denies any oropharyngeal swelling.  No lip or tongue swelling.  No wheezing or shortness of breath.  No headache.  No nausea.  Notes itchy rash, especially on his torso and upper arms.
Hey, bud. What brings you in today?
A rash on my upper arms and torso.
When did it start?
Bout a day or two ago.
Any itchiness to the area?
Yes, a lot actually.
Have you had episodes of shortness of breath or wheezing?
No.
How about swelling to your lips, tongue, or throat?
No.
And no nausea or headaches?
No.
Have you applied anything to the rash?
No, I thought it'd go away on its own.
You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: Essentially unchanged from her visit of 04/15/2005.
Has anything changed in your medical history since you last visit on April fifteenth two thousand five?
What do you mean by that?
Have you been diagnosed with any new medical conditions, or are you experiencing any new symptoms?
Oh, no, nothing like that.
You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: Accutane.
How've you been treating your acne?
The dermatologist started me on Accutane.
How long have you been on Accutane?
About three months now.
Have you noticed any improvements since starting it?
Yeah, kinda.
You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: Confusion and hallucinations.
Have you been experiencing any mental difficulties or confusion?
No.
Any hallucinations? Are you seeing hearing thing that is not real?
No.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: 32 weeks gestation to a G4 mother and weighed 4#11oz. He was placed in an incubator for 3 weeks. He was jaundiced, but there was no report that he required treatment.
How is his birth history? Was he born normal? Or was there any abnormality?
He was born at thirty two weeks. He was my fourth pregnancy, and he was around four pounds and eleven ounces.
Was he placed in an incubator?
Yes, he was there for three weeks. He had jaundice but they didn't give any treatment for it.
You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: He has not had any previous surgery.
Have you had any surgeries in the past?
Nope I have not.
Anything?
No.
You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: Back pain after a fall.
Hello. How are you doing today?
Not great. My back is killing me.
What happened?
I fell down on it.
I see. Let's do some tests to see if you damaged anything.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: The patient has a history of inhalation on intravenous drug abuse.  She is currently on methadone maintenance.  She is being followed in Psychiatry for depression and substance abuse issues.  She lives with a room-mate.
When are you planning to quit your I V and inhalation drugs Mister X Y Z?
I am on treatment now. They are following me up for depression issues too.
Okay yes, you are on methadone maintenance.
Yes.
Who lives with you?
I have a roommate.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: The patient is a 57-year-old female being seen today for evaluation of pain and symptoms related to a recurrent bunion deformity in bilateral feet, right greater than left.  The patient states she is having increasing symptoms of pain and discomfort associated with recurrence of bunion deformity on the right foot and pain localized to the second toe and MTP joint of the right foot as well.  The patient had prior surgery performed approximately 13 years ago.  She states that since the time of the original surgery the deformity has slowly recurred, and she has noticed progressive deformity in the lesser toes at the second and third toes of the left foot and involving the second toe of the right foot.  The patient is employed on her feet as a hospital employee and states that she does wear a functional orthotic which does provide some relief of forefoot pain although not complete.
Good afternoon, ma'am.
Good afternoon, doctor.
Before we begin, how old are you?
I'm fifty seven years old.
Very well, and what seems to be the problem today?
So, I had surgery on these feet, um, like thirteen years ago to remove bunions, but they're back now.
I see, are these bunions present on both feet?
Yeah, they are.
Is one foot worse than the other?
Yeah, my right foot is worse than the left.
Is the pain getting worse?
Yes, and I'm so uncomfortable.
On the right foot, do you have any other pain? Or is it just because of the bunion?
Well, I have some pain here, and here.
Okay, just so you know, these are the second toe, and M T P joint. This is where you're feeling the pain, right?
Yes, it hurts so bad there.
There's some deformity here at the second toe as well.
Yes, I see what you're talking about.
Going back to that surgery thirteen years ago, did you heal up well?
Since that surgery this bunion has slowly been coming back.
I see.
Please, look at my left foot, do those toes look strange to you?
Yes, you have that deformity in the second and third toes of the left foot as well.
What does that mean?
It means you have some arthritis in these toes. What do you do for a living?
I see. I work in the hospital.
Can I assume you're on your feet all day for work?
Yes, I have to stand all day every day.
Do you wear supports, or any kind of orthotics?
Yes, I wear orthotics.
Do those provide any relief?
They definitely give me some relief, but I'm still in so much pain.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: She was born, normal spontaneous vaginal delivery at Woman's weighing 7 pounds 3 ounces.  No complications.  Prevented, she passed her hearing screen at birth.
Hi, I will ask about some birth related questions about your baby, okay?
Yeah, sure.
Was she born normal or cesarian?
No cesarian, there was normal delivery. It was spontaneous too.
Where was she born?
At the Women's.
What was her weight at birth?
She weighed seven pounds three ounces.
Any complications?
No.
Was there any hearing test?
Yeah, she cleared her all her screening tests.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: He denies tobacco or alcohol.  He has what sounds like a data entry computer job.
So, where do you work?
Oh, I am a data operator for an I T company.
Okay.
Do you smoke or drink?
No, I don't!
You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: To home with his son.
Who are going to stay with?
I am going home with my son. I will stay with him.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: He immigrated to this country in 1984, although he lists himself as having a green card still at this time.  He states he lives on his own.  He is a single male with no history of marriage or children and that he had high school education.  His recreational drug use in the chart indicates that he has had a history of methamphetamines.  The patient denies this at this time.  He also denies current alcohol use.  He does smoke.  He is unable to tell me of any PCP.  He is in counseling service with his case manager being XYZ.
When did you move here from Philippines, sir?
I think somewhere around nineteen eighty four.
Oh wow, it's been a while, do you have a green card?
Yes I do have G C. My apartment is not too far from there.
Do you live by yourself? Or you married?
No, I live by myself. Never been married or widowed or kids.
Okay what have you studied?
I finished high school. But I do work.
Okay. Do you drink alcohol or smoke?
I do smoke but no alcohol.
How about drugs?
I used to but not anymore.
Which one?
Meth.
Okay. Do you have a P C P?
No. But I have a case manager, Mister X Y Z. He is making me go to counselling
Okay. Can I get the notes?
Yes, I can ask them to send you.
Okay that will be good.
Awesome!

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: The patient is a 62-year-old African-American male with a significant past medical history of diabetes, hypertension, previous stroke in 2002 with minimal residual right-sided weakness as well as two MIs, status post pacemaker insertion who first presented with numbness in his lower extremities in 2001.  He states that since that time these symptoms have been progressive and now involving his legs above his knees as well as his hands.  More recently, he describes a burning sensation along with numbness.  This has become a particular problem and of all the problems he has he feels that pain is his primary concern.  Over the last six months, he has noticed that he cannot feel hot objects in his hands and that objects slip out of his hands.  He denies any weakness per se, just clumsiness and decreased sensation.  He has also been complaining of brief muscle jerks, which occur in both hands and his shoulders.  This has been a fairly longstanding problem, and again has become more prevalent recently.  He does not have any tremor.  He denies any neck pain.  He walks with the aid of a walker because of unsteadiness with gait. Recently, he has tried gabapentin, but this was not effective for pain control.  Oxycodone helps somewhat and gives him at least three hours pain relief.  Because of the pain, he has significant problems with fractured sleep.  He states he has not had a good night's sleep in many years.  About six months ago, after an MI and pacemaker insertion, he was transferred to a nursing facility.  At that facility, his insulin was stopped.  Since then he has only been on oral medication for his diabetes.  He denies any back pain, neck pain, change in bowel or bladder function, or specific injury pre-dating these symptoms.
How old are you, sir?
I am sixty two year old African American.
Do you have any relevant past medical history?
I do have diabetes, high blood pressure and I had a stroke in the year two thousand and two. I do have weakness on my right side after that. I also had two heart attacks. Ah.
Any history of surgery?
I have a pacemaker.
It shows here that you came to us in two thousand and one for weakness and numbness in your legs. How is that now?
Oh, it was never gone. Instead, it has also moved to my hands and areas above my knees.
What are your symptoms now?
It's mostly like something is burning and numbness is still there.
Is that your main concern?
Yeah, it is. That is my main problem. I do have pain, but it is not that much of a concern.

For the last six months, I cannot feel anything hot in my hands. Things slip out of my hand. I don't have any weakness as such, but it's just like that feeling of clumsiness and it's just lots of sensation.
Sometimes I feel, like, these jerks in my body, mainly my shoulders and both hands.
Has it been for some time?
It has been like forever but now I am noticing it more than before.
Do you get any kind of tremors?
No.
Any neck pain?
No, but as you might have noticed I am using this walker because I do not feel safe walking.
Have you used anything for your pain?
Yeah, they tried different medicines but only oxycodone helped a little. It does give me sometimes around three hours of relief. Gabapentin did not work at all.
How is your sleep?
I cannot sleep properly because of the pain. It has been for many years. I haven't had a proper sleep.
When did you get your pacemaker?
It was around six months ago after the heart attack and pacemaker I was transferred to a nursing home. There they stopped my insulin and since then, I'm taking tablets for that.
Do you have any back pain?
Nope.
Any change in bathroom routine?
No.
Did you ever have any accidents or any injury before all this started?
No, nothing like that.
You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: The patient does not have any chief complaint.
Hi, how can I help?
No, I just came in for follow up.
Okay so just a follow up today. No complaints?
Nope. Nothing.
That's great.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: Patient is hard of hearing.  She also has vision problems.  Denies headache syndrome.  Presently, denies chest pain or shortness of breath.  She denies abdominal pain.  Presently, she has left hip pain and left shoulder pain.  No urinary frequency or dysuria.  No skin lesions.  She does have swelling to both lower extremities for the last several weeks.  She denies endocrinopathies.  Psychiatric issues include chronic depression.
Just to go over few things let me ask, any aches and pains?
Currently I just have left hip pain and shoulder pain.
Oh, how bad is it?
Pretty bad.
What else is going on?
I have this leg swelling from last couple weeks.
Any new skin lesions on your legs from the swelling?
No.
How about problems with urination and abdominal pain?
No problems with urination.
How about chest pain or shortness of breath or hormonal imbalances?
No I don't have any such problems, except I have vision and hearing problems.
You have chronic depression right?
Yes that is correct.
Any sort of headaches?
No.
What about thyroid dysfunction?
You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: lives with parents and attends mainstream 5th grade classes.
Hi there! I am Doctor Frankland.
Hi. It is nice to meet you.
How are you today?
I'm good.
Do you live at home with both of your parents?
Yes.
What grade are you in?
Firth grade.
Mom, is he in public school?
Yes.
Is he enrolled in any special education classes?
No. He is in all the regular mainstream classes.
Great!

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: The patient comes in today because of feeling lightheaded and difficulty keeping his balance.  He denies this as a spinning sensation that he had had in the past with vertigo.  He just describes as feeling very lightheaded.  It usually occurs with position changes such as when he stands up from the sitting position or stands up from a lying position.  It tends to ease when he sits down again, but does not totally resolve for another 15 to 30 minutes and he feels shaky and weak all over.  Lorazepam did not help this sensation.  His blood pressure has been up lately and his dose of metoprolol was increased.  They feel these symptoms have gotten worse since metoprolol was increased.
What brings you here today, sir?
I'm feeling a lot of lightheadedness and I just cannot keep stable. I'm losing my balance all the time.
Do you have any spinning sensation?
No, but I had it before when I had vertigo. I'm just feeling lightheaded.
Is it happening after anything special you are doing? What symptoms are you witnessing?

Whenever I'm trying to change my positions like standing from sitting or getting up from the bed it is happening. Normally sitting back down helps. But it is not completely gone for like fifteen to thirty minutes. I feel very shaky and weak.
Are you taking any medications for that?
Ah yes, I was taking lorazepam, but it did not help with the sensation.
Anything else going on?
Um, my blood pressure was up so they increased my dose of metoprolol for it. They think all these symptoms are because of the increased dose. I just wanted to check in with you as well.
You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: No medications other than recent amoxicillin.
Are you taking any medication?
Yes, I am taking that antibiotic.
Oh yes!
Yeah.
Yes, you are taking amoxicillin.
That's right.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: 1.  Bipolar disorder. 2.  Iron deficiency anemia. 3.  Anxiety disorder. 4.  History of tubal ligation.
I see that the patient was in yesterday.
Yes, she's a frequent flyer.
What's her medical history?
She suffers from bipolar disorder and anxiety. She's also anemic and not on any iron supplements. As for surgeries, she's had her tubes ligated.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: He is a non-cigarette smoker and non-ETOH user.  He is single and he has no children.  He works as a payroll representative and previously did lot of work in jewelry business, working he states with chemical.
Do you smoke?
No, I do not.
How about alcohol.
No, I don't drink alcohol as well.
Okay let me ask you, do you have any children or are you married?
No, I am single, thus no kids.
Okay, where do you work?
I work as a payroll representative. I used to do a lot of work in jewelry business, with chemical.
interesting.
Yeah.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: The patient was seen in the urgent care and examined.  At this time, her photophobia and nausea make migraine highly likely.  She is well appearing and we'll try Tylenol with codeine for her pain.  One day off school and follow up with her primary doctor.
I looked over your report from urgent care.
They didn't do much other than tell me to follow up with you.
Given that you're sensitive to light and feel nauseated, I believe a migraine is highly likely.
Can I take anything for it?
I'm going to prescribe you Tylenol with codeine to help your pain.
Can I get a doctor's note, too?
Yes. In fact, I'd like you to take a day off from school and rest until you start to feel better.
Okay. Thank you.
You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: Include Cipro and Flagyl.
Let me write you a prescription for Cipro and Flagyl.
Okay.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: This is a 51-year-old right hand dominant female with a longstanding history of pain as well as locking sensation to her right thumb.  She was actually able to spontaneously trigger the thumb.  She was diagnosed with stenosing tendinosis and wishes to proceed with release of A1 pulley.  All risks and benefits of the surgery was discussed with her at length.  She was in agreement with the above treatment plan.
Hello, ma'am. How are you doing today?
My right hand hurts.
Is that your dominant hand?
It is.
I see. What seems to be the problem?
I feel like my right thumb just locks up, and I can't move it anymore.
Does it stay locked?
No, it doesn't. It just moves out of nowhere. Like right now!
I can see that. Have you seen someone about your thumb before?
I have. These are the notes from that visit. Here you go.
Thank you. It looks liked you were diagnoses with stenosing tendinosis, which is trigger finger.
Is that common for a fifty one year old woman like me?
Yeah, it is. We can proceed by releasing the A one pulley?
Could you describe what that means? Could you also go over the risks and benefits of the surgery?
Of course. I'll explain it and give it to you in writing.
Thank you. I'll most likely agree to it. I need to fix this thumb.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: The patient is keeping a food journal that she brought in.  She is counting calorie points, which ranged 26 to 30 per day.  She is exercising pretty regularly.  She attends Overeaters Anonymous and her sponsor is helping her and told her to get some ideas on how to plan snacks to prevent hypoglycemia.  The patient requests information on diabetic exchanges.  She said she is feeling better since she has lost weight.
Are you keeping up with your food journal?
Yes, and I have it with me today.
Good, and you're using calorie points, correct?
Yes, I range from twenty six to thirty.
Good, are you exercising regularly?
Yes, I am. I'm also going to Overeaters Anonymous.
How is that going?
Good, my sponsor is helping me, and told me to think about snacks that can help with my high blood sugar. That was what we talked about last.
Good, all of that is good to hear.
I'm feeling a lot better, and I've lost weight, but do you have any information on diabetic exchanges, doctor?
You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: Noncontributory.
Any significant family history of disease?
None according to my records.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: Partial colon resection of colon carcinoma in 1961 with no recurrence, cholecystectomy 10 years ago, appendectomy, and glaucoma surgery.
Have you ever had surgery?
One too many times.
Which ones?
I had my appendix taken out and glaucoma surgery fairly recently. I also had my gallbladder taken out ten years ago and a partial colon resection due to colon cancer in nineteen sixty one.
Any recurring episodes of colon cancer?
No, thankfully.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: The patient's only surgery is the aforementioned left knee arthroplasty and bilateral cataract surgery, otherwise negative.
What is your surgical history?
I had cataract surgery on both eyes. I also had knee replacement surgery on my left knee.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: Family history is remarkable for heart disease, cerebrovascular disease, diabetes, and hypertension.
Hi, there. How are you doing?
I think I have some sort of condition.
Why do you say that?
My body has been feeling weird lately.
I see. Is there anything that runs in your family?
I know a lot of my family has some sort of heart problem. We have high blood pressure and blood sugar. There's one more thing. It starts with a C. Something to do with the brain. Do you know?
Is it cerebrovascular disease?
There you go. How'd you get that so fast?
I guess I know my stuff.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: This is a 52-year-old gentleman with a long history of heroin abuse, who keeps relapsing, presents once again, trying to get off the heroin, last use shortly prior to arrival including cocaine.  The patient does have a history of alcohol abuse, but mostly he is concerned about the heroin abuse.
Hi mister Jones. Do you remember me from the last time you were here? How old are you now?
I am fifty two. Yes doc. I remember you.
What have you been using most recently? I need to know what kind of drugs we are dealing with.
I gotta kick the heroin. It's going to kill me this time. Please help me. My whole body hurts. I am so cold.
Okay. Is there anything else that you been using recently? Alcohol? Pills?
I did some coke. It's this heroin that is going to get me. I used to abuse alcohol, but now I have switched to drugs.
You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: Noncontributory.
Anyone sick in your family?
No one.
Okay.
Everyone is healthy.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: His father died of colon and thyroid cancers at age 52. One brother died of stomach cancer at age 53 and one brother committed suicide. Five other siblings are all healthy. Negative for coronary heart disease, hypertension, diabetes, or kidney disease.
Tell me a little more about your family. Are there any significant conditions that your parents or siblings had that you know of?
Um, my dad died a few years back. He had color cancer and thyroid cancer.
I'm so sorry to hear that, sir. How old was he?
Thank you, he was only fifty two.
That's tragic, I'm sorry. What about your siblings?
I have seven total. One of my brothers died from stomach cancer when he was fifty three and another brother committed suicide.
I'm so sorry to hear that. Can I assume your other siblings are healthy?
Yes sir, they're all doing very well.
That's good. Do you have any other conditions, like heart disease, high blood pressure, diabetes, or kidney disease?
Nope, I keep pretty healthy.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: 1. Take medications regularly. 2. PT, OT, speech therapist to evaluate and treat at Siskin Rehab Hospital. 3. Continue Cipro for an additional two days for his UTI.

I have sent over your referral for physical therapy, occupational therapy and speech therapy. The patient coordinator at Siskin Rehab Hospital will give you a call within two days to see up your appointments. It is important to take your medications regularly. You need to continue the Cipro for an additional two days only. That will take care of the U T I. Do you have any questions?
No.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: Mother died at the age of 59 due to stomach cancer and father died at the age of 91 years old.
Can you tell me about cancer in your family?
Yes, my mom had stomach cancer and she died at fifty nine.
And father?
My dad died at ninety one years of age.
Okay.
You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: Negative.  Generally very healthy.
Does she have any past medical history or health problems?
No. She is a healthy child.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: All labs within normal limits with the exception of Sodium 133, Creatinine 0.2, TSH 0.004, Free T4 19.3 EKG showed sinus tachycardia with a rate of 122.  Urine pregnancy test was negative.

I looked at your labs. Everything looks normal for the most part. You do have abnormal levels for Sodium and Creatinine which are related to your kidneys. Then your thyroid levels are not normal as well.
How about my E K G? I had a negative pregnancy test.
Oh yes that. Your E K G showed a higher heart rate of one twenty two per minute. We will evaluate everything further.

You are a medical chatbot. You should help the patient by answering their questions and providing advice about the following topic: The patient returns today for a followup.  She was recently in the hospital and was found to be septic from nephrolithiasis.  This was all treated.  She did require a stent in the left ureter.  Dr. XYZ took care of this.  She had a stone, which was treated with lithotripsy.  She is now back here for followup.  I had written out all of her medications with their dose and schedule on a progress sheet.  I had given her instructions regarding follow up here and follow with Dr. F.  Unfortunately, that piece of paper was lost.  Somehow between the hospital and home she lost it and has not been able to find it.  She has no followup appointment with Dr. F.  The day after she was dismissed, her nephew called me stating that the prescriptions were lost, instructions were lost, etc.  Later she apparently found the prescriptions and they were filled.  She tells me she is taking the antibiotic, which I believe was Levaquin and she has one more to take.  She had no clue as to seeing Dr. XYZ again.  She says she is still not feeling very well and feels somewhat sick like.  She has no clue as to still having a ureteral stent.  I explained this to she and her husband again today.
Good morning. So, you are here for your follow up today.
Yes, sir.
Update me what happened, why were you in the hospital?

I had a lot of back pain and less of urine output. I always had burning sensation whenever I used to go to the bathroom. So, I went to the doctor, and they said it is kidney stones. I knew something was wrong, but then I started having fever. So, I went to the hospital and they said that it was infection. It all began with my kidney stones.
I see. So how are you feeling now?
I'm feeling better. The burning sensation is gone. Pain has subsided.
It says that they put a stent in your ureter. Are you feeling any discomfort with it? Who was your doctor there?
No discomfort, I'm just here for my follow up. Doctor X Y Z did operate on me to remove all those stones, the kidney stones. She is a good doctor. She did take care of me. I feel all new now.

That's nice to hear. I'm glad you are feeling okay. You remember I wrote down all the medications with their doses on your progress note, a sheet that we gave to you. Your nephew called me and he said that the prescription was lost and instructions were lost. What happened there?

I don't know. I remember you gave me a paper saying it has all the medicines. It's everything related to them and all the things that I have to do. But I don't know what happened between the hospital and the home. I completely lost it. And I don't know where did it go.

It had instructions to follow up here and also to follow up with Doctor F. Do you have an appointment with Doctor F? You never did call me after the day you were dismissed from the hospital saying that you might have lost the paper that we gave to you.

No, unfortunately I don't have any appointment with Doctor F. I was not even aware about that, that I have to take an appointment because maybe it was only there in the paper. It completely got out of my mind. Somehow, I did find the prescription paper where all the medicines were and I was able to get them filled and I was taking all my antibiotics and everything else which was there.
